feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 4:08PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Above 3000 Feet After Midnight Tonight... Snow levels will drop to 2000-3000 ft across the Interior, Brooks Range and Alaska Range after midnight tonight. Little if any snow will accumulate below 3000 ft, while an inch or two of snow will accumulate by Saturday morning in areas above 3000 ft. Areas in the Alaska Range above 4000 ft could see 4-6 inches of snow by
entry.cap:areaDesc: Denali; Eastern Alaska Range; Middle Tanana Valley; Southeastern Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands

cap:geocode.value: AKZ218 AKZ219 AKZ220 AKZ222 AKZ225 AKZ226

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 4:08PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water on the Tanana River and Tributaries Draining the Alaska Range into the Weekend... High water on the Tanana River and tributaries draining the Alaska Range will continue into the weekend. This includes the Chisana River, Nabesna River, Gerstle River, Delta River, and the Nenana River. The Tanana River is running at bankfull.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Deltana and Tanana Flats; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 12:39PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...ELEVATED WATER LEVELS EXPECTED FOR KUSKOKWIM DELTA COAST TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT... TONIGHT`S THREAT: Persistent west-southwesterly flow today into tonight coinciding with high tide and higher seas could raise water levels 1 to 2 feet above normal highest tide, especially between Newtok and Kipnuk.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 01 at 9:48PM PDT until September 02 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT PDT TONIGHT FOR SOUTHEASTERN INYO COUNTY... At 948 PM PDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Up to 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued September 01 at 10:11PM EDT until September 02 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...One half foot of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. * WHERE...Surry, Isle of Wight and Norfolk/Portsmouth Counties, and Suffolk and Chesapeake.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 01 at 9:28PM CDT until September 02 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM CDT SATURDAY... * WHAT...High waves and dangerous currents expected. * WHERE...Beaches along Lake Michigan in Door, Kewaunee and Manitowoc Counties. * WHEN...Thru 7 AM CDT Saturday.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 01 at 3:11PM CDT until September 02 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 AM CDT SATURDAY... * WHAT...Life threatening waves of 2 to 4 feet and dangerous currents are expected. * WHERE...Sheboygan and Ozaukee Counties. * WHEN...Until 1 AM CDT Saturday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 2:48PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...NEAR-CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS SUNDAY AND LABOR DAY... Fire weather concerns are expected on Sunday and Labor Day as hotter air moves into the region, afternoon relative humidity values drop into the 20s and 30s and southwest winds gust to around 25 mph. Under these conditions, fires will start and spread easily.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lincoln; Marathon; Oneida; Portage; Waupaca; Waushara; Wood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 01 at 2:25PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...ELEVATED TO NEAR CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH LABOR DAY... The combination of low relative humidity values, temperatures in the 80s, southerly winds and dry fuels will result in elevated fire weather conditions this afternoon across parts of southwest and central Wisconsin.
